passages.text: The minutes from the RBAs August meeting were dovish, though came and went with little fanfare. The decision to ease by 25bp was unanimous, so the minutes didn't offer up any alternative scenarios for the August decision, though members agreed further easing will likely be required to achieve the inflation/ employment objectives. The J.P. Morgan Hawk Dove Score ranked the minutes as a dovish shift relative to July, though still more hawkish than the May meeting where officials discussed the merits of a 50bp cut.

We find RBA and RBNZ HDS have historically exhibited lower betas to Fed rhetoric relative to other DM central banks. We think this relationship will be preserved in coming quarters, with the Fed likely to ease policy by 100bp over the next four meetings \((4\times 25\mathrm{bps})\) , outpacing the RBA \((1\times 25\mathrm{bp})\) and RBNZ \((2\times 25\mathrm{bp})\) . Australia - US cross market expressions have looked particularly attractive given the former's growth outlook and greater fiscal capacity. We take profit on our paid AUD- USD 2Yx2Y (IRS- SFR) position, but remain paid the Dec '25 RBA- FOMC OIS spread.

The minutes sounded the death knell for active QT, stating that the Bank's "bond holdings should continue to run down as they mature and that this matter no longer warranted active consideration". With that in mind, the RBA's balance sheet reduction has, to date, been among the most rapid across DM with the TFF expiration reducing reserves by \(\sim \mathrm{A}\$ 200\) billion. Based on the composition of RBA bond holdings, the balance sheet is on a trajectory to halve by late- 2028.

Australia's monthly CPI indicator for July printed at \(2.8\%\) oya, significantly stronger than our forecast \((2.3\%\) oya) and underpinned by an unexpected spike in electricity prices \((13\% \mathrm{m / m})\) . Electricity prices have swung wildly in the past two years following the implementation of government cost of living subsidies, with the reported price spike owing to the next installment landing in August, rather than July. Accordingly, out- of- pocket costs for households in these regions should revert lower in the next print, taking some of the heat off the headline numbers.

Inflation breake yens shrugged off this week's minutes and monthly CPI release, with the short tenors pushing modestly wider, the belly unchanged, and long- end narrowing. Our bias remains towards widening expressions in the belly and longer dat e thines which continue to screen cheap relative to the RBA's inflation target. Trade portfolio: Close the paid AUD- USD 2Yx2Y (IRS- SFR) position for a profit of \(+37.5\mathrm{bp}\) , stay paid Dec '25 RBA- FOMC OIS spread. Receive the NZD \(2\sfrac{5}{5}\) IRS curve spread vs AUD.
Australian and New Zealand Interest Rate Strategy

- The RBA's August meeting minutes were dovish, with board members noting further cuts will be required to achieve the inflation and employment objectives- The J.P. Morgan Hawk Dove Score ranked the minutes as a dovish shift relative to July, though still more hawkish than the May meeting where officials discussed the merits of a 50bp cut- We expect the Fed to ease policy by 100bp over the next four meetings (4x25bps), outpacing the RBA (1x25bp) and RBNZ (2x25bp)- We've favoured paid AUD-US expressions given the relative GDP growth and fiscal outlooks. We take profit on our paid position in the AUD-USD 2Yx2Y (IRS-SFR) spread, but remain paid Dec '25 RBA-FOMC OIS- The minutes sounded the death knell for active QT, stating that the Bank's "bond holdings should continue to run down as they mature and that this matter no longer warranted active consideration"- Australia's monthly CPI indicator for July printed at 2.8%oya, significantly stronger than our forecast (2.3%oya) and underpinned by an unexpected spike in electricity prices (13%m/m)- The upside in electricity relates to the timing of government subsidies and should revert lower in the next print, taking some of the heat off the headline number- Inflation markets shrugged off this week's minutes and monthly CPI release, with the short tenors pushing modestly wider, the belly unchanged, and long-end narrowing- Our bias remains towards widening expressions in the belly/longer dated lines which continue to screen cheap relative to the RBA's inflation target- Trade portfolio: Close paid AUD-USD 2Yx2Y (IRS-SFR) position, remain paid the Dec '25 RBA-FOMC OIS spread. Receive the NZD 2s/5s IRS curve spread vs AUD.

The minutes to the RBA's August meeting skewed dovish, though came and went with little fanfare. The decision to lower the cash rate by 25bp was unanimous, while there remains general agreement that "some further reduction in the cash rate over the coming year" would likely be required to achieve the central bank's employment/inflation objectives. The subsequent discussion steps through the merits of a "gradual" versus "slightly faster" pace of easing, but comes to the conclusion "it was not yet possible to judge between these alternative scenarios for the pace of future reduction in the cash rate, given the prevailing uncertainties".

Based on JPM Hawk Dove Scores (NLP summary) the minutes marked an incremental dovish shift relative to July (Figure 1), though still slightly more hawkish than May's meeting, where the RBA discussed easing policy by 50bp. From a cross market perspective, August's dovish tilt preserves the RBA - RBNZ HDS spread following the latter's surprisingly dovish commentary at its August meeting (Figure 2). In previous research we've explored the correlation of cross-market HDS using PCA and found most central bank commentary follows a common single factor (principal component (PC)1), which appears to act as a proxy for inflation. Unsurprisingly, RBA and RBNZ HDS have been very closely correlated with PC1 in recent years given the surge in
Figure 1: The RBA's August minutes skewed down but are still aligned with the policy statement
Hawk Dove Score. Higher value is more hawkish
Source: RBA, J.P. Morgan.
Figure 2: The August minutes preserved the antipodean HDS spread on a like-for-like basis
Source: RBA, RBNZ, J.P. Morgan.

PC2 more closely aligns with a 'Follow the Fed' indicator, at least outside the periods where the Fed is very dovish. Interestingly, the RBA and RBNZ have historically displayed a relatively low correlation with PC2 (Figure 3), a relationship which has persisted in recent years despite the commonality in policy drivers (i.e. inflation). In our view these correlations will be preserved in coming quarters, with the Fed forecast to ease policy by 100bp over the next four meetings (4x25bps), outpacing the RBA (1x25bp) and RBNZ (2x25bp).

Our portfolio is already positioned to capture these dynamics. We close our paid AUD- USD 2Yx2Y (IRS- SFR) position for a profit of \(+37.5\mathrm{bp}\) given this spread is now realigning with the previous range. We remain paid Dec '25 RBA- FOMC OIS and expect this trade to benefit from Australia's firmer growth outlook and greater fiscal capacity, both of which take pressure off monetary policy. These macro factors also support flattening on a domestic (RBA under- delivering) and cross- market (fading real term premia) basis, with Australia's 3s/10s curve steep in outright terms and versus the US (Figure 4).
Figure 3: Antipodean central banks have empirically displayed a low correlation with PC2
For more refer to Talk is Cheap: Valuing DM Rates Markets with Central Bank Speak. Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 4: Australia's 3s/10s curve is steep in outright terms and versus the US
X axis: AUD 3s/10s cash curve (bp); Y axis: US 2s/10s cash curve (bp)
Dark blue is relationship since Jan 2022, light blue is 2025 observations Source: J.P. Morgan.

The August minutes also included an update on the Bank's thinking around balance sheet size and asset composition. To date, the Bank has maintained a passive approach to balance sheet management, allowing bond holdings to run down as they mature but reviewing the appropriateness of this method on a periodic basis. The August minutes took a slightly different turn, noting that in the "absence of persuasive arguments from either a policy or a risk- reduction perspective, the Board determined that bond holdings should continue to run down as they mature and that this matter no longer warranted active consideration".

The RBA was widely expected to maintain a passive approach regarding its balance sheet, though this week's announcement shoots down any residual prospect of a more activist QT program. With that in mind, the RBA's balance sheet adjustment has been one of the more rapid across DM economies, with the expiration of the Term Funding Facility (TFF) reducing the RBA's balance sheet/excess reserves by \(\sim \mathrm{A}\mathrm{S}200\) billion since 2023 (Figure 5). We expect the pace of adjustment will slow from here, but given the RBA's bond holdings are concentrated in the shorter- dated lines (Figure 6) the balance sheet is still on track to halve in size by late- 2028.
Figure 5: TFF expiration resulted in a rapid contraction in the RBA's balance sheet
Shaded area reflects expected balance sheet unwind. Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 6: RBA bond holdings are concentrated in short dated tenors Ihs: A\$bn, rhs: % of GDP
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Australia's monthly CPI indicator for July printed at \(2.8\%\) (Figure 7), significantly stronger than our forecast \((2.3\%)\) and underpinned by an unexpected spike in electricity prices \((13\%)\) m). Electricity prices have swung wildly in the past two years following the implementation of government cost of living subsidies, with this week's reported price spike owing to the next installment landing in August, rather than July. (Figure 8). Accordingly, out- of- pocket costs for households in these regions should revert lower in the next print, taking some of the heat off the headline CPI print.

Despite the magnitude of the forecast miss, we don't think this week's print has material implications for monetary policy with the RBA likely to look through the July data. Indeed, if our view on subsidies is correct then household electricity costs in NSW/ACT should decline in August as payments resume. Further, inflation is still target consistent and aligned with our view for a rebound to the upper half of the band.
Figure 7: Both headline and core inflation turned higher, but remain within the central bank's target band %
Source:ABS,J.P.Morgan.
Figure 8: July's inflation spike mostly owed to the timing of subsidies
June 2023,index \(= 100\)
a. Introduction of the 2023-24 Commonwealth Energy Bill Relief Fund (EBRF) rebates
b. Introduction of the first instalment of the 2024-25 EBRF rebates for all households in QLD and WA, and State rebates in QLD, WA and TAS
c. Introduction of the first instalment of the extended 2024-25 EBRF rebates for all households in VIC, QLD, SA, TAS and NT
Source:ABS,J.P.Morgan.

Breakevens were little changed this week (Figure 9), with the short- dated lines pushing wider, the belly unchanged, and a small narrowing in the long- end. Accordingly, our view on the curve hasn't changed in the wake of the minutes or monthly CPI indicator, and we continue to favour widening expressions in the belly/longer dated lines which still screen cheap relative to the RBA's inflation target.

On a cross- market basis, front- end spreads remain deeply negative and reflect the largely idiosyncratic tariff shock expected to hit US goods prices. The belly and longer dated lines have widened from recent rights, but remain low in the range which may reflect more of Australia's beta to (negative) global demand shocks playing out in real yields, rather than BEI. Our bias is for modest breakeven outperformance in the 2040 and 2050 lines given the respective central bank inflation targets, though levels are admittedly less compelling than earlier in the year.
Figure 9: Australian breakevens were little changed this week despite dovish RBA minutes and a strong CPI indicator
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P., J.P. Morgan.
Figure 10: AU-US breakevens appear cheap on a cross market basis bp
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P., J.P. Morgan.

Analyst Certification: The Research Analyst(s) denoted by an "AC" on the cover of this report certifies (or, where multiple Research Analysts are primarily responsible for this report, the Research Analyst denoted by an "AC" on the cover or within the document individually certifies, with respect to each security or issuer that the Research Analyst covers in this research) that: (1) all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect the Research Analyst's personal views about any and all of the subject securities or issuers; and (2) no part of any of the Research Analyst's compensation was, is, or will be directly or indirectly related to the specific recommendations or views expressed by the Research Analyst(s) in this report. For all Korea- based Research Analysts listed on the front cover, if applicable, they also certify, as per KOFIA requirements, that the Research Analyst's analysis was made in good faith and that the views reflect the Research Analyst's own opinion, without undue influence or intervention.

All authors named within this report are Research Analysts who produce independent research unless otherwise specified. In Europe, Sector Specialists (Sales and Trading) may be shown on this report as contacts but are not authors of the report or part of the Research Department.

A history of J.P. Morgan investment recommendations disseminated during the preceding 12 months can be accessed on the Research & Commentary page of http://www.jpmorganmarkets.com where you can also search by analyst name, sector or financial instrument.

Ratings System: J.P. Morgan uses the following issuer portfolio weightings for Emerging Markets Sovereign Research: Overweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to outperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark credit returns); Marketweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to perform in line with the relevant index, sector, or benchmark credit returns); and Underweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to underperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark credit returns). NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating for this security because of either legal, regulatory or policy reasons or because of lack of a sufficient fundamental basis. The previous rating no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. NC is Not Covered. An NC designation is not a rating or a recommendation. Recommendations will be at the issuer level, and an issuer recommendation applies to all of the index- eligible bonds at the same level for the issuer. When we change the issuer- level rating, we are changing the rating for all of the issues covered, unless otherwise specified. Ratings for quasi- sovereign issuers in the EMBIG may differ from the ratings provided in EM corporate coverage.

Valuation & Methodology: For J.P. Morgan's Emerging Markets Sovereign Research, we assign a rating to each sovereign issuer (Overweight, Marketweight or Underweight) based on our view of whether the combination of the issuer's fundamentals, market technicals, and the relative value of its securities will cause it to outperform, perform in line with, or underperform the credit returns of the EMBIG index over the next three months. Our view of an issuer's fundamentals includes our opinion of whether the issuer is becoming more or less able to service its debt obligations when they become due and payable, as well as whether its willingness to service debt obligations is increasing or decreasing.
